title: Hinkley nuclear deal: China could start building its own reactor in UK in 2022
text:
2,501.11 +25.11 
Chinese reactor technology in line to be used in Essex in return for funding French reactors to be built in Somerset. 
China could be allowed to start building its own nuclear reactor in Essex as soon as 2022, in return for providing £6 billion funding for Britain’s first new nuclear plant to go ahead at Hinkley Point in Somerset. 
In a deal hailed as “historic” by David Cameron, Chinese state nuclear company CGN took a one-third stake in the £18 billion Hinkley project led by French state energy giant EDF (Paris: FR0010242511 - news ) , which said it now expected to begin construction within weeks . 
EDF announced it would also help CGN seek approval from UK safety regulators for its own Hualong reactor design, never before used in the West, in a process that is expected to begin next year and take three to four years. 
If successful, CGN would then apply for planning permission to build the reactor at Bradwell in Essex and seek a subsidy contract from the Government, potentially enabling it to start construction in 2022 or 2023, Vincent de Rivaz, EDF Energy chief executive said. 
The go-ahead (LSE: GOG.L - news ) for EDF’s Hinkley Point plant has been almost a decade in the making, and heralds the start of a decade of construction before first power is now expected in 2025 eight years later than originally envisaged. 
Ministers have agreed that UK energy bill-payers will pay subsidies to the plant for the power it produces for up to 35 years, in a deal that analysts estimate could add £13 to bills in 2026 . 
The plant will generate enough electricity to power 5.8 million homes, EDF (Hanover: E2F.HA - news ) said, and will employ 5,600 people in construction the “vast majority” of them British. In total, 25,000 jobs could be created by the project, it claimed. 
EDF said the £18 billion cost estimate for Hinkley was the amount that would have been spent by the time the project is completed, including the effects of inflation over the decade-long construction period. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) said this was in line with a previous £16 billion estimate it had given, which had been expressed in 2012 prices. 
A £24.5 billion estimate from the European Commission was now “irrelevant” as that was based on an old funding model that EDF had now abandoned, it said. 
The company had planned to take out up to £16 billion in project financing loans using taxpayer-backed guarantees offered by the Chancellor. Under its new funding model, it may now only use an initial £2 billion loan guarantee announced last month. 
Amber Rudd, the energy secretary, said: “The UK is open for business and this is a good deal for everyone Hinkley Point C will continue to meet our robust safety regulations and will power nearly six million households with low-carbon energy, creating over 25,000 jobs and more financial security for working people and their families.”
